_**Dr. Seuss ' The Cat in the Hat**_ is a 2003 American
[family](/wiki/Children%27s_film "Children's film") [comedy
film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") directed by [Bo Welch](/wiki/Bo_Welch
"Bo Welch"). It is based on the 1957 [Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss "Dr. Seuss")
book _[of the same name](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat")_. The
film stars [Mike Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers "Mike Myers") in the title role of
the Cat in the Hat, and [Dakota Fanning](/wiki/Dakota_Fanning "Dakota
Fanning") as Sally. Sally's brother (who is unnamed in the book and the [1971
TV special](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(TV_special\) "The Cat in the Hat \(TV
special\)")), Conrad, is portrayed by [Spencer Breslin](/wiki/Spencer_Breslin
"Spencer Breslin"). The film is the second feature-length Dr. Seuss adaptation
after the 2000 holiday film _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_\(2000_film\)
"Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas \(2000 film\)")_.

The idea was originally conceived in 2001, with [Tim Allen](/wiki/Tim_Allen
"Tim Allen") initially cast as the Cat, but he dropped his role due to work on
_[The Santa Clause 2](/wiki/The_Santa_Clause_2 "The Santa Clause 2")_ , and
the role was later given to Myers. Filming took place in
[California](/wiki/California "California") for three months. While the basic
plot parallels that of the book, the film filled out its 82 minutes by adding
new [subplots](/wiki/Subplot "Subplot") and characters significantly different
from the original story, similar to the feature film adaptation of _[How the
Grinch Stole Christmas](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_!_\(film\) "How
the Grinch Stole Christmas ! \(film\)")_.

Released on November 21, 2003 in the United States, the film grossed $134
million worldwide.[3] After the film's release, Seuss' widow, [Audrey
Geisel](/wiki/Audrey_Geisel "Audrey Geisel"), decided not to allow any further
live-action adaptations of Seuss' works to be produced, and as a result, a
planned [sequel](/wiki/Sequel "Sequel") based on _[The Cat in the Hat Comes
Back](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_Comes_Back "The Cat in the Hat Comes Back")_
was cancelled.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Conrad and Sally Walden live in the city of Anville with their mother, Joan
Walden. Joan works for neat-freak Hank Humberfloob, and is hosting an office
party at her house. One day, she is called back to the office, leaving the
kids with Mrs. Kwan, a tired babysitter, and forbidding them to enter the
living room, which is being kept pristine for the upcoming party. Joan is also
dating their next-door neighbor, Larry Quinn, much to Conrad's dismay. Larry
is constantly on the lookout for any mischief Conrad may be up to, as he wants
nothing more than to send him away to [military school](/wiki/Military_school
"Military school"), as Conrad has earned the reputation of "hot-headed
[trouble-maker](/wiki/Rebellion "Rebellion")", while his sister is
characterized as "perfect and well-behaved".

Once their mother leaves, Sally and Conrad meet a humanoid, oversized talking
cat in a hat in their house. The cat reveals he wants them to learn to have
fun, but the children's pet fish doesn't want the cat around when Joan is
away. The Cat balances some stuff, ruins Joan's best dress, jumps on the
living room's couch, and bakes cupcakes that explode. In the process, he
releases two trouble-making things, Thing 1 and Thing 2, from a crate that he
explains is actually a portal to another world. The Cat tells Conrad that he
only has one rule: never open the crate, then allows the Things to have fun,
but they make a mess of the house. Despite the Cat's warning, Conrad picks the
lock on the crate. When the crate's lock attaches itself to the collar of the
family dog, Nevins, Cat and the kids must go find him and the lock. They drive
a super-powered car in search of Nevins and use Cat's magic hat. Conrad
realizes that the Things always do the opposite to what they are told. and
that this can be used to their advantage and has them stall Joan.

Meanwhile, Larry is revealed to be a fat, unemployed man with false teeth and
is in financial ruin, though claiming he is a successful businessman in the
hopes of marrying to Joan and sponging off of her. Larry sees Nevins running
across the street and tracks down Joan to tell her, but Things 1 and 2 have
stalled her on the road, posing as police officers. Larry goes back to the
house, telling Joan to meet him there.

By the time the kids and the Cat return to the house with the lock, a huge
mess spills from the unlocked crate and enters the house. They navigate their
way through the oversized house and find the crate while cleaning up. The
house is returned to its normal proportions but then immediately falls apart.
The Cat tells the kids that he planned the whole day, including making not
opening the crate his one rule, as he knew Conrad could not resist. The kids
angrily tell the Cat to leave the house. Conrad prepares to face the
consequences when Joan comes home, but Sally says she will share the blame.
The Cat, having overheard this, happily returns to clean up the mess with a
great cleaning contraption. Afterwards The Cat says goodbye and departs as
Joan is arriving. Larry arrives when all is restored, thinking he has busted
the kids, but when Joan sees the clean house (and a messy Larry), she does not
believe Larry and rejects him. After the successful party, Joan spends time
with her children and the Cat finishes narrating. The film ends as he and his
things decide to go on a vacation.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Mike Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers "Mike Myers") as [the Cat in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat"), a huge, [anthropomorphic](/wiki/Anthropomorphic "Anthropomorphic"), wise-cracking [cat](/wiki/Cat "Cat") with a [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn") accent who wears a special hat which reveals many magical abilities.
  * [Spencer Breslin](/wiki/Spencer_Breslin "Spencer Breslin") as Conrad Walden, Joan's destructive and misbehaved son.
  * [Dakota Fanning](/wiki/Dakota_Fanning "Dakota Fanning") as Sally Walden, Joan's dull, well-behaved, and rule-obeying daughter.
  * [Kelly Preston](/wiki/Kelly_Preston "Kelly Preston") as Joan Walden, Conrad and Sally's mother, and a [workaholic](/wiki/Workaholic "Workaholic") [real-estate agent](/wiki/Real-estate_agent "Real-estate agent").
  * [Alec Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec Baldwin") as Larry Quinn, the Waldens' pompous, lazy, unemployed next-door neighbor. He is revealed to be allergic to cats, steals food from the Waldens and gets away with it, and is determined to both marry Joan for her wealth and send Conrad to [military school](/wiki/Military_school "Military school") to straighten up his behavior.
  * [Amy Hill](/wiki/Amy_Hill "Amy Hill") as Mrs. Kwan, an elderly Taiwanese woman who gets hired to watch the kids, though she sleeps through her job. Her weight and sleep serves as a running gag.
  * [Sean Hayes](/wiki/Sean_Hayes_\(actor\) "Sean Hayes \(actor\)") as Mr. Hank Humberfloob, Joan's boss. Hayes is also the voice of the family fish.
  * [Danielle Chuchran](/wiki/Danielle_Chuchran "Danielle Chuchran") and Taylor Rice as Thing One, and Brittany Oaks and Talia-Lynn Prairie as Thing Two; two gibbering trouble-making creatures that the Cat brings in with him. [Dan Castellaneta](/wiki/Dan_Castellaneta "Dan Castellaneta") provided the voices for both Things.
  * [Steven Anthony Lawrence](/wiki/Steven_Anthony_Lawrence "Steven Anthony Lawrence") as Dumb Schweitzer
  * [Paris Hilton](/wiki/Paris_Hilton "Paris Hilton") as a female club-goer
  * Bugsy as Nevins, the Waldens' pet dog. [Frank Welker](/wiki/Frank_Welker "Frank Welker") provided his voice.
  * [Candace Dean Brown](/wiki/Candace_Brown "Candace Brown") as a secretary who works for the Humberfloob Real Estate.
  * [Daran Norris](/wiki/Daran_Norris "Daran Norris") as the Astounding Products Announcer
  * [Clint Howard](/wiki/Clint_Howard "Clint Howard") as Kate the Caterer
  * [Paige Hurd](/wiki/Paige_Hurd "Paige Hurd") as Denise, who doesn't speak to Sally anymore, not long after she talked back to her. She never invited Sally to her birthday party either since Sally earlier stated that she told Denise not to speak to her anymore.
  * [Stephen Hibbert](/wiki/Stephen_Hibbert "Stephen Hibbert") as Jim McFinnigan
  * Roger Morrisey as Mr. Vompatatat
  * [Victor Brandt](/wiki/Victor_Brandt "Victor Brandt") as the Narrator, who tells the story; he is revealed to be the Cat using a voice-changer at the end.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

DreamWorks acquired rights to the original book in 1997.[4] However,
production did not originally start until after the 2000
[Christmas](/wiki/List_of_Christmas_films "List of Christmas
films")/[comedy](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") film _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_\(2000_film\)
"Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas \(2000 film\)")_ , based on
[another Dr. Seuss book of the same
name](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas! "How the Grinch Stole
Christmas!"), became a commercial success. [Brian Grazer](/wiki/Brian_Grazer
"Brian Grazer"), who was the producer of _The Grinch_ , stated, "Because we
grew up with these books, and because they have such universal themes and the
illustrations ignite such fantasy in your mind as a child — the aggregation of
all those feelings — it leaves an indelible, positive memory. And so when I
realized I had a chance to convert first _The Grinch_ and then, _The Cat in
the Hat_ , into movies, I was willing to do anything to bring them to the
screen."[5] Grazer contacted [Bo Welch](/wiki/Bo_Welch "Bo Welch") over the
phone with the offer to direct the film, and he accepted.[6] When production
began, songs written by [Randy Newman](/wiki/Randy_Newman "Randy Newman") were
dropped because they were deemed inferior. Newman's cousin, David Newman,
composed the score for the film. Although Welch and a publicist for Myers
denied it, several people said Myers had considerable input into the film's
direction, telling some of the cast (co-stars Baldwin and Preston) how to
perform their scenes.[7]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Casting")]

[Tim Allen](/wiki/Tim_Allen "Tim Allen") was originally planned to play the
role of the Cat. The script would be originally based on a story conceived by
Allen, who admitted that as a child he was afraid of Seuss' "mischievous
feline" babysitter. Allen stated, "My dream is to give it the edge that scared
me."[8] However, producers did not commission a screenplay until late February
2001, when [Alec Berg](/wiki/Alec_Berg "Alec Berg"), [Jeff
Schaffer](/wiki/Jeff_Schaffer "Jeff Schaffer"), and [Dave
Mandel](/wiki/Dave_Mandel "Dave Mandel") (who were also writers on
_[Seinfeld](/wiki/Seinfeld "Seinfeld")_) were hired to write the script
(replacing the original draft of the film that was written a few years
before),[9] so the film would not be ready to shoot before the deadline. Allen
was also committed to shooting [Disney's](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt
Disney Pictures") _[The Santa Clause 2](/wiki/The_Santa_Clause_2 "The Santa
Clause 2")_ , which was also delayed because Allen wanted a script
rewrite.[10] Due to a scheduling conflict with _The Santa Clause 2_ ,[11] he
dropped out his role.[12] In March 2002, the role of the Cat was given to
[Mike Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers "Mike Myers"),[13] even though he had an
argument with Grazer about starring in a cancelled _[Saturday Night
Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ skit named
_[Dieter](/wiki/Sprockets_\(Saturday_Night_Live\)#Proposed_film_adaptation
"Sprockets \(Saturday Night Live\)")_.[14] Myers stated in an interview that
he was a long-time fan of the original [Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss "Dr.
Seuss") book, and that it was the first book he ever read.[15]

### Makeup and visual
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Makeup and visual effects")]

Makeup for the character was designed by [Steve
Johnson](/wiki/Steve_Johnson_\(special_effects_artist\) "Steve Johnson
\(special effects artist\)"). The Cat costume was made of
[angora](/wiki/Angora_wool "Angora wool") and human hair and was fitted with a
cooling system. To keep Myers cool during the outdoor shoots, a portable air
conditioner was available that connected a hose to the suit between shots. The
tail and ears were battery operated.[16] The Fish was considered somewhat of a
unique character for Rhythm & Hues (responsible for some of the effects and
animation in such films as _[Cats& Dogs](/wiki/Cats_%26_Dogs "Cats & Dogs")_,
_[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the
King](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Return_of_the_King "The Lord of the
Rings: The Return of the King")_ , and _[Scooby-Doo](/wiki/Scooby-Doo_\(film\)
"Scooby-Doo \(film\)")_), in that the character had no shoulders, hips or
legs, so all of the physical performance had to emit from the eyes, head and
fin motion. Sean Hayes, who provided the voice for the Fish, found the role
significantly different from his usual on-camera jobs; he did not know how the
final animation would look, and all of his work took place alone in a sound
booth.[17]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Filming")]

Prior to filming, giant props for the film were stolen from the set. Local
police found the props vandalized in a mall car park in [Pomona,
California](/wiki/Pomona,_California "Pomona, California"). The props were
covered with graffiti. No arrests had been made, and filming was to start the
next week.[18] [Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal
photography") took place mostly in [California](/wiki/California "California")
from October 2002 until January 2003. The neighborhood and the town centre was
filmed in a rural valley near [Simi Valley](/wiki/Simi_Valley,_California
"Simi Valley, California"), where 24 houses (each 26-feet square and 52-feet
tall) were constructed.[19] The downtown area outdoor shots were filmed along
a [Pomona](/wiki/Pomona,_California "Pomona, California") street where a
number of antique and gift shops are located. The community decided not to
redecorate after filming ended, so the surreal paint scheme and some of the
signage could still be seen as it appears in the film. Because of so much
[smog](/wiki/Smog "Smog") in the area, the sky had to be digitally replaced
with the cartoon-like sky and colours of the background had to be digitally
fixed.

##
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Music")]

The Cat in the Hat  
---  
[Film score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") / [Soundtrack
album](/wiki/Soundtrack_album "Soundtrack album") by [David
Newman](/wiki/David_Newman_\(composer\) "David Newman \(composer\)")  
Released | November 18, 2003  
Recorded | 2002  
[Genre](/wiki/Music_genre "Music genre") | [Orchestra](/wiki/Orchestra "Orchestra")  
Length | 48:55  
[Label](/wiki/Record_label "Record label") | [BMG Soundtracks](/wiki/Bertelsmann_Music_Group "Bertelsmann Music Group")  
  
The soundtrack was released on November 18, 2003.[20] It includes [David
Newman](/wiki/David_Newman_\(composer\) "David Newman \(composer\)")'s score,
plus a song by [Smash Mouth](/wiki/Smash_Mouth "Smash Mouth") ("[Getting
Better](/wiki/Getting_Better "Getting Better")") and ("[Hang
On](/wiki/Get_the_Picture%3F_\(Smash_Mouth_album\) "Get the Picture? \(Smash
Mouth album\)")") that makes it the third film in a row playing a song in an
film starring [Mike Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers "Mike Myers"), after
_[Shrek](/wiki/Shrek "Shrek")_ (2001) and _[Austin Powers in
Goldmember](/wiki/Austin_Powers_in_Goldmember "Austin Powers in Goldmember")_
(2002). The soundtrack also includes a couple of songs performed by Mike Myers
(the role of the Cat). Newman's score won a [BMI Film Music
Award](/wiki/BMI_Film_Music_Award "BMI Film Music Award").

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Release")]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Home media")]

_The Cat in the Hat_ was released for [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") and
[DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") on March 16, 2004.[21] It features 16 [deleted
scenes](/wiki/Deleted_scene "Deleted scene"), 20 [outtake](/wiki/Outtake
"Outtake") scenes, almost a dozen featurettes, and a “Dance with the Cat”
tutorial to teach kids a Cat in the Hat dance.[22] On February 7, 2012, the
film was released on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc").[23]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Cat in the Hat_ opened theatrically on November 21, 2003 and earned
$38,329,160 in its opening weekend, ranking first in the North American box
office.[24] The film ended its theatrical run on March 18, 2004, having
grossed $101,149,285 domestically and $32,811,256 overseas for a worldwide
total of $133,960,541.[2]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Critical response")]

Review aggregate website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes") reported a 10% approval rating based on reviews from 158 critics.
The website's consensus reads: "Filled with double entendres and potty humor,
this _Cat_ falls flat."[25] On [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"),
the film has a score of 19/100 based on 37 reviews, indicating "overwhelming
dislike".[26] It also received an average grade of _D+_ from critics in the
interpretation of [Yahoo](/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!")'s film website.[27]

[Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ gave the film one star, stating,
"_Cat_ , another over-blown Hollywood raid on [Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss "Dr.
Seuss"), has a draw on Mike Myers, who inexplicably plays the Cat by mimicking
[Bert Lahr](/wiki/Bert_Lahr "Bert Lahr") in _[The Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939 film\)")_."
[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ gave the film 2 out of 4
stars. Although he praised the production design, he considered the film to be
"all effects and stunts and CGI and prosthetics, with no room for lightness
and joy".[28] Ebert and co-host Richard Roeper gave the film "Two Thumbs
Down". Roeper said of Myers' performance that "Maybe a part of him was
realizing as the movie was being made that a live-action version of _The Cat
in the Hat_ just wasn't a great idea." Ebert had the same problem with the
film that he had with _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_\(2000_film\)
"Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas \(2000 film\)")_ , in that "If
there is one thing I've learned from these two movies is that we don't want to
see [Jim Carrey](/wiki/Jim_Carrey "Jim Carrey") as a Grinch, and we don't want
to see Mike Myers as a cat. These are talented comedians, let's see them do
their stuff, don't bury them under a ton of technology."

Concerns were also raised over the [PG](/wiki/MPAA_film_rating_system "MPAA
film rating system") rating of the film with some critics, stating that it
should have instead been rated PG-13 in relation to its high amount of adult
content.[29]

[Leonard Maltin](/wiki/Leonard_Maltin "Leonard Maltin") in his [Movie
Guide](/wiki/Leonard_Maltin%27s_Movie_Guide "Leonard Maltin's Movie Guide")
gave it one and a half stars out of four saying that the "Brightly colored
adaptation of the beloved rhyming book for young children is a betrayal of
everything Dr. Seuss ever stood for, injecting potty humor and adult (wink-
wink) jokes into a mixture of heavy-handed slapstick and silliness." Maltin
also claimed that the film's official title which included _**Dr Seuss '** The
Cat in the Hat_ was "an official insult."[30] However, Jeffrey Lyons from NBC-
TV, enjoyed the film and considered it "enormously funny".[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Baldwin addressed complaints the film received because of its dissimilarity to
the source material. He expressed a belief that a film is "an idea about
something" and that because Dr. Seuss' work is so unique, making a feature-
length film out of one of his stories would entail taking liberties and making
broad interpretations.[31]

## Cancelled
sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Cancelled sequel")]

On the day of the film's release, Mike Myers stated in an interview that he
expected a [sequel](/wiki/Sequel "Sequel"), since there was a sequel to the
book. A sequel based on _[The Cat in the Hat Comes
Back](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat#The_Cat_in_the_Hat_Comes_Back "The Cat in the
Hat")_ was in development, a little more than a month before the film's
release.[34] In February 2004, Dr. Seuss' widow, [Audrey
Geisel](/wiki/Audrey_Geisel "Audrey Geisel"), said she would never allow any
further live action adaptations of her husband's works, and the sequel was
eventually cancelled.[35]

## Animated
reboot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Animated reboot")]

On March 15, 2012, a [computer animated](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer
animation") ([CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-generated
imagery")) reboot of the film was announced by [Universal
Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures") and [Illumination
Entertainment](/wiki/Illumination_Entertainment "Illumination Entertainment"),
following the success of _[The Lorax](/wiki/The_Lorax_\(film\) "The Lorax
\(film\)")_.[36][37][38][39][40][41][42]

_**The Cat in the Hat**_ is a 2003 [platformer](/wiki/Platform_game "Platform
game") video game released by [Vivendi Universal Games](/wiki/Vivendi_Games
"Vivendi Games") and developed by [Magenta Software](/wiki/Magenta_Software
"Magenta Software") and [Digital Eclipse](/wiki/Backbone_Entertainment
"Backbone Entertainment"). It is based on the film of the same name. The game
was released for [PlayStation 2](/wiki/PlayStation_2 "PlayStation 2"),
[Xbox](/wiki/Xbox_\(console\) "Xbox \(console\)"), and [Game Boy
Advance](/wiki/Game_Boy_Advance "Game Boy Advance") on November 5, 2003, and
[PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer") on November 9, 2003, shortly
before the film's theatrical release. A version for the [Nintendo
GameCube](/wiki/Nintendo_GameCube "Nintendo GameCube") was planned to be
release, but was later cancelled.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\)&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Plot")]

The plot of the game is different from the film; instead of Conrad unlocking
the Cat's Crate, Larry unlocks it and steals the Lock. Playing as the Cat, the
player must go through thirteen levels through the transformed house and chase
down Larry, who is collecting the magic released from the Crate for himself,
and defeat him to get the Lock (called the "Crablock" in-game) back and re-
lock the Crate before the children's mother returns home.[43]
